Trait description: The uniformity of the plant
Method description: Observe the uniformity of the plant and rate it
Category 1: 5 = Intermediate (50% of the plants show height, vigor and growth stage heterogeneity)
Category 2: 3 = Heterogeneous (75% of the plants show height, vigor and growth stage heterogeneity.)
Category 3: 9 = Very uniform (100% of the plants show height, vigor, growth stage homogeneity)
Category 4: 7 = Uniform (75% of the plants show height, vigor and growth stage homogeneity)
Category 5: 1 = Very heterogeneous (Height, vigor, growth stage very heterogeneous.)

Trait description: The vigor of the plant
Method description: Observe the vigor of the plant and rate it
Category 2: 3 = Weak 95% of the plants are small (< 20 cm) or all the plants are between 20 and 30 cm, the plants have few leaves, thin stems and/or light green color)
Category 3: 9 = Very vigorous (All the plants are over 70 cm and ground coverage is complete. The plants are robust, with thick stems and abundant foliage of dark green color)
Category 4: 7 = Vigorous (75% of the plants are over 50 cm, robust with foliage of dark green color, thick stems and leaves very well developed)
Category 5: 1 = Very weak (All the plants are small (< 20 cm), few leaves, weak plants, very thin stems and/or light green color)

Trait description: The senescence of the plant
Method description: Observe the senescence of the plant and rate it
Category 1: 5 = Medium (the plants are still being green or on the onset of senescence, there may be a slight yellowing. The angle of insertion of the leaves on the stems may have become more obtuse than in the younger plants of the same clone. The formation of berries can be advanced and abundant in fertile clones)
Category 2: 3 = Late (Most of the plants are still green, flowering is over and berries might be formed)
Category 3: 9 = Very early (The plants are completely senescent, yellowing is complete and uniform, and the stems are decumbent)
Category 4: 7 = Early (The plants have senescent foliage, yellowing is more advanced but the stems may still be upright. If berries are present, their color will turn from green to pale green or yellow green.)
Category 5: 1 = Very late (All the plants still show green foliage and flowers)

Trait description: The number of stolons
Method description: Observe the number of stolons and rate it
Category 3: 9 = Very high (Plants with more than 25 stolons)
Category 5: 1 = Very few (Plants show no stolon or very few (0 to 4))

Trait description: The length of stolons
Method description: Observe the length of stolons and rate it

Trait description: The appearence of the tuber
Method description: Observe the appearence of the tuber and rate it
Category 1: 5 = Regular (Medium yield, good shape but non uniform size)
Category 2: 3 = Poor (Low yield, some misshapes but non uniform size)
Category 3: 9 = Very good (High yield, good shape and very uniform size)
Category 4: 7 = Good (Good yield, good shape and uniform size)
Category 5: 1 = Very poor (Very low yield, totally misshapes and non-uniform size)

Trait description: The uniformity of the tuber
Method description: Observe the uniformity of the tuber and rate it
Category 1: 5 = Intermediate (There are only 2 or 3 tuber sizes with a predominant size)
Category 2: 3 = Heterogeneous (All tuber sizes are present but there is a predominant size)
Category 4: 7 = Uniform (Only two sizes are present with a predominant tuber size)
Category 5: 1 = Very heterogeneous (All tuber sizes are present (from very small to large))

Trait description: The size of the tuber
Method description: Measure the size of the tuber and rate it
Category 4: 7 = Large (Tubers are large, between 6 and 9 cm.)
Category 5: 1 = Very small (Most tubers are very small (<2cm).)

Context of use: Each plant should be measured with a ruler or a measureing tape after hilling but before drought treatments
Trait description: The plant height of the main stem
Method description: Measure the Plant height and record it. Height should be taken from the tip of the plant to the ground level.

Trait description: The grade of stress of the plant
Method description: Compute Stress intensity using the formula

Trait description: The wilting of the canopy
Method description: Observe the Degree of canopy wilting and rate it
Category 1: 1=No wilting (All the plants still show green foliage and turgid)
Category 2: 3=Slight (Most of the plants are still green and turgid, 25 % plants with in the plot show slight wilting evidence by leaf dropping (wilting) and rolling in the bottom of the canopy)
Category 3: 5=Medium (50 % of the plants show leaf rolling in the bottom of the canopy, moderate wilting of leaves throughout the canopy and some loss of petiole turgidity)
Category 4: 7=Severe (75% of the plants show wilt: the petioles severely wilted and dry leaves in the bottom of the canopy)
Category 5: 9=Very severe (100% of the plants show very severe water stress: completely wilted plant and dry leaf)

Trait description: The drought susceptibility of the plant
Method description: Compute Drought susceptibility index using the formula
Formula: {1 -[total tuber weight per plot of stressed environment/total tuber weight per plot of nonstressed environment]}/susceptibility index

Trait description: The drought tolerance of the plant
Method description: Compute Drought tolerance index using the formula
Formula: [total tuber weight per plot of stressed environment*total tuber weight per plot of nonstressed environment)]/[great mean of total tuber weight per plot of nonstressed environment]}
